newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight interbank rate remains at 5.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight interbank rate remains at 5.5 pct.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate remained at 5.5 percent on Thursday, pressured by high market liquidity and lending by big local banks as well as foreign banks, dealers said.
"The situation has not changed. The market remains long and the big banks are still lending," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
But despite the liquid market, interbank rates were expected to stabilise around current levels, he said.
Dealers said some big banks continued to tap cheaper funds offshore and lending at the short-end.
"If you can borrow offshore at 3.8-4.0 percent, why not take advantage of it," said another dealer.
Dealers said players remained cautious over the situation in Thailand, although Wednesday's move by the Bank of Thailand to float the baht had no spillover effect here.
Earlier, one-week money was at 6.40/50 percent against 6.30/35 on Wednesday.
One-month money was steady at 7.25 percent, and three-month at 7.35/40 percent against 7.40/45.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were lower across the board.
At 0900 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was down nine points to 92.58, or an implied yield of 7.42 percent.
The December contract fell six to 92.73, or 7.27 percent while March 1998 was down five points to 92.74, or 7.26 percent.
